entry.title: Congrats Dr. Teng Gao!
entry.content: Park lab says congratulations to lab member Teng Gao who defended his thesisSomatic genome evolution in cancer and aging through the lens of transcriptionthis April. Congrats Teng!
entry.summary: Park lab says congratulations to lab member Teng Gao who defended his thesisSomatic genome evolution in cancer and aging through the lens of transcriptionthis April. Congrats Teng!

entry.title: Park Lab at RECOMB
entry.content: Peter and lab members Flora, Sandra, Yifan, Yuwei, Allen, and Dominik attended the RECOMB sattelite workshops in Cambridge. Below are pictures of Peter giving a talk and Yifan presenting!
entry.summary: Peter and lab members Flora, Sandra, Yifan, Yuwei, Allen, and Dominik attended the RECOMB sattelite workshops in Cambridge. Below are pictures of Peter giving a talk and Yifan presenting!

entry.title: Harvard vs Yale Hockey Game
entry.content: Park lab attended the Harvard vs Yale hockey game on Friday! The lab cheered Harvard on to a 2-1 OT win.
entry.summary: Park lab attended the Harvard vs Yale hockey game on Friday! The lab cheered Harvard on to a 2-1 OT win.

entry.title: Farewell Yoo-Na!
entry.content: Park lab gathered to say goodbye to Yoo-Na as her time here as a visiting scholar working on ctDNA analysis ended. Yoo-Na returns to her clinical fellowship and role as a Research Assistant Professor in gynecologic oncology in Korea.
entry.summary: Park lab gathered to say goodbye to Yoo-Na as her time here as a visiting scholar working on ctDNA analysis ended. Yoo-Na returns to her clinical fellowship and role as a Research Assistant Professor in gynecologic oncology in Korea.

entry.title: Park Lab Holiday Party 2023!
entry.content: After a brief hiatus, Park lab members past and present gathered together to celebrate the holiday season. A few active members were unable to join during this busy time: Benedikt Geiger, Shannon Ehmesen, Joe Luquette, Greg Brunette, Teng Gao, Bianca Morris, Rahi Navelkar.
entry.summary: After a brief hiatus, Park lab members past and present gathered together to celebrate the holiday season. A few active members were unable to join during this busy time: Benedikt Geiger, Shannon Ehmesen, Joe Luquette, Greg Brunette, Teng Gao, Bianca Morris, Rahi Navelkar.

entry.title: Kayaking on the Charles River!
entry.content:
The lab had a fun and adventurous time kayaking together on the Charles this August!

Unfortunately, we failed to get Peter Park and Dominik Glodzik in the picture but they also attended.
entry.summary: The lab had a fun and adventurous time kayaking together on the Charles this August!

entry.title: Antuan’s Farewell Dinner
entry.content: The lab said goodbye and good luck to Antuan as he heads onto his next adventure in medical school at Mayo Clinic!
entry.summary: The lab said goodbye and good luck to Antuan as he heads onto his next adventure in medical school at Mayo Clinic!

entry.title: Researchers identify new mechanism of oncogene amplification in breast cancer

link.title: Researchers identify new mechanism of oncogene amplification in breast cancer

entry.content:
“In this new study, led by SPECIFICANCER co-investigator Peter Park of Harvard Medical School, US, and his postdoctoral fellow Jake Lee, the researchers used whole-genome sequencing, RNA sequencing and epigenomic data to uncover the origin of focal oncogene amplifications in breast cancer.”

Read the whole story here: The Mark Foundation for Cancer Research: Researchers identify new mechanism of oncogene amplification in breast cancer
entry.summary: “In this new study, led by SPECIFICANCER co-investigator Peter Park of Harvard Medical School, US, and his postdoctoral fellow Jake Lee, the researchers used whole-genome sequencing, RNA sequencing and epigenomic data to uncover the origin of focal oncogene amplifications in breast cancer.”

entry.title: Congratulations Dr. Viswanadham!
entry.content: Congratulations to Vinay for graduating this year with a PhD! At 369 pages, his thesis “Origins, patterns, and consequences of somatic mutations in engineered, normal, and diseased cells” spans multiple areas including tracking the pattern of somatic mutations in the brain at the single cell level, identifying off-target effects of genome editing with single cell whole-genome sequencing, and finding the impact of somatic structural alterations that disrupt non-coding regions. Awesome work, Dr. Viswanadham!
entry.summary: Congratulations to Vinay for graduating this year with a PhD! At 369 pages, his thesis “Origins, patterns, and consequences of somatic mutations in engineered, normal, and diseased cells” spans multiple areas including tracking the pattern of somatic mutations in the brain at the single cell level, identifying off-target effects of genome editing with single cell whole-genome sequencing, and finding the impact of somatic structural alterations that disrupt non-coding regions. Awesome work, Dr. Viswanadham!
